description.narrative: Mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity conservation into production sectors in the East Godavari, Andhra Pradesh.
second-order administrative division

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: Community livelihoods and natural resource use are sustainable in the EGREE
Number of SHGs CBOs strengthened

comment.narrative: In 44 abutting villages 709 SHGs 20 EDCs 16 Fishermens Association 33 Womens Organization 5 NGOs 17 Youth Clubs and 5 Dairy Cooperatives are strengthened

1 NRM environmental awareness programmes were carried out for nature clubs formed with the help of schools colleges and universities in the EGREE region through the GoIUNDPGEFGoAP Godavari Project 2 3 more Village Youth clubs were formed to promote NRM programmes through EGREE Foundation
In 44 abutting villages 709 SHGs 20 EDCs 16 Fishermens Association 33 Womens Organization 5 NGOs 17 Youth Clubs and 5 Dairy Cooperatives are strengthened

1 NRM environmental awareness programmes were carried out for nature clubs formed with the help of schools colleges and universities in the EGREE region through the GoIUNDPGEFGoAP Godavari Project 2 3 more Village Youth clubs were formed to promote NRM programmes through EGREE Foundation

description.narrative: Number of skills development activities carried out for SHGs CBOs and other local institutions for alternative and or sustainable ecosystembased livelihoods that reduce pressures on biodiversity

comment.narrative: Target to be defined after design of the microplans

3 The project has carried out a total of 518 programmes reaching out to 11736 people as detailed below
a Skill Enhancement Programme Skill Trainings and Exposure Visits Conducted Skill Training and Exposure visits 19 programmes involving 402 people on fish post harvesting technology industrial motivational campaigns Micro Small and Medium Entrepreneurship MSME and development programmes training on Apparel Designing and Fashion Technology etc for women groups youth and SHGs computer training for youth training for cooperatives in commodities marketing for earning better incomes and thus enabling them to improve their quality of life Exposure trips to Fishery Research Institutes Cooperatives Dairy development Institutes Alternative Livelihood options to the youth women and other dependents of the natural resources of EGREE
b Institutional Strengthening Capacity Building Conducted 24 Capacity building programmes for 497 members of EDC VSS CBOs NGOs Cooperatives SHGs Line Departments youth groups and Panchayats Strengthened EDCs20 VSS9 Women Groups20 Cooperatives3 Youth Clubs5 NGOs4
c Awareness building programmes Conducted 196 Awareness building programmes for 4630 members on sustainable fisheries management systems grazing regime and fuel wood extraction defined under the developed microplans
d Village level meetings Consultations and Tieups Conducted Village level Consultations 280 with resource users 6207 people for discussing rights and responsibilities village development motivation capacity building and distribution of supporting implements modifications to catch size fishing tools nets etc better management of fishing activity to minimize associated waste generated etc
e Networking Building Social Capital Initiated Networking 6 networks Sarpanch Samikya Sangham Forest Protection Groups Federation of Ecodevelopment committees and Vansmarakshana Samities and Fishermen groups District Fishermen Association and village leaders for a Better governance and for initiating pro conservation activities b Strengthening the networks c Activating the village assembliesGramasabhas for discussing and addressing the village development and biodiversity conservation activities Micro plans
Target to be defined after design of the microplans

c Awareness building programmes Conducted 196 Awareness building programmes for 4630 members on sustainable fisheries management systems grazing regime and fuel wood extraction defined under the developed microplans

description.narrative: Number of people shifting to alternative livelihood options that reduce pressure on biodiversity

comment.narrative: Baseline to be collected in Year 1
Target to be defined after design of the microplans

Based on the recommendations of the microplans the project is implementing livelihood and awareness generation activities in 37 villages in the project area Among them 10 high dependent villages have been highly prioritized and resource development alternative livelihood activities have been initiated in these villages through the Andhra Pradesh Forest and Fisheries Depts
I Fishery development of post harvest technology to the fisher men and women and supporting technically improved equipment In addition 1 Strengthening the village infrastructure a Community halls which were in bad shape were renovated as community extension and information centers and are now being used for conducting meetings awareness programmes educating the youth club women groups on biodiversity conservation etc b Constructed fish drying yard and dairy milk collection center to support the resource users for enhancing their livelihood opportunitiesc Supported construction of a hygienic market and landing space at Matlapalem with the collaboration of Fisheries department Kakinada d Fish processing centre at Chollangi Snanala Revu Highway fish stall at Kobbarichettu Peta villages e Conducted pilot fish stall with the trained women at Kakinada town to tie up with local and district retail market network for sales and marketing of the processed fish f Distributed Ecofriendly Fishing gear to 7 fishermen groups 70 fishermen at Matlapalem village
II Promoting alternative livelihoods and collaboration with institutions 2 Provided Microcredit support for establishing Micro Entrepreneurship programme to Matlapalem Uppalanka and Clollangi Snanala Revu villages based on this initiated linking this programme with AP State Government Programme Capital Infusion Fund through District Rural Development Agency DRDA EG Dt
3 Created linkages between the trained candidates of Nature Guides and Cookery courses with Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation APTDC
4 EF established Alternative Livelihood training center SMART Skill Camp in collaboration with ATDC Hyd Ministry of Jute and Textile and imparted training to 50 community women The women initiated DISHA society for textile designing and manufacturing unit Initiated tieup with DRDA industrial textile manufacturing units industries for bulk orders to the trained women
III Promoting Community based EcoTourism
5 Strengthening of Community Based Eco Tourism CBET Supported the Forest Department to construct and procure necessary infrastructure for strengthening of CBET at Chollangi and Ramannapalem Jetty Gate Arch Dust bins Murals Eco autos Publicity material etc
6 Also the Forest Department has allocated land for constructing a Centre for Community Knowledge on Coastal Conservation CCKCC under the umbrella of the EGREE Foundation
Target to be defined after design of the microplans

Based on the recommendations of the microplans the project is implementing livelihood and awareness generation activities in 37 villages in the project area Among them 10 high dependent villages have been highly prioritized and resource development alternative livelihood activities have been initiated in these villages through the Andhra Pradesh Forest and Fisheries Depts
I Fishery development of post harvest technology to the fisher men and women and supporting technically improved equipment In addition 1 Strengthening the village infrastructure a Community halls which were in bad shape were renovated as community extension and information centers and are now being used for conducting meetings awareness programmes educating the youth club women groups on biodiversity conservation etc b Constructed fish drying yard and dairy milk collection center to support the resource users for enhancing their livelihood opportunitiesc Supported construction of a hygienic market and landing space at Matlapalem with the collaboration of Fisheries department Kakinada d Fish processing centre at Chollangi Snanala Revu Highway fish stall at Kobbarichettu Peta villages e Conducted pilot fish stall with the trained women at Kakinada town to tie up with local and district retail market network for sales and marketing of the processed fish f Distributed Ecofriendly Fishing gear to 7 fishermen groups 70 fishermen at Matlapalem village
II Promoting alternative livelihoods and collaboration with institutions 2 Provided Microcredit support for establishing Micro Entrepreneurship programme to Matlapalem Uppalanka and Clollangi Snanala Revu villages based on this initiated linking this programme with AP State Government Programme Capital Infusion Fund through District Rural Development Agency DRDA EG Dt
3 Created linkages between the trained candidates of Nature Guides and Cookery courses with Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation APTDC
4 EF established Alternative Livelihood training center SMART Skill Camp in collaboration with ATDC Hyd Ministry of Jute and Textile and imparted training to 50 community women The women initiated DISHA society for textile designing and manufacturing unit Initiated tieup with DRDA industrial textile manufacturing units industries for bulk orders to the trained women
III Promoting Community based EcoTourism
5 Strengthening of Community Based Eco Tourism CBET Supported the Forest Department to construct and procure necessary infrastructure for strengthening of CBET at Chollangi and Ramannapalem Jetty Gate Arch Dust bins Murals Eco autos Publicity material etc
6 Also the Forest Department has allocated land for constructing a Centre for Community Knowledge on Coastal Conservation CCKCC under the umbrella of the EGREE Foundation

description.narrative: Incidents of felling of mangrove trees nonadherence to the seasonal ban on fishing destructive fishing practices by local communities within the project area in contravention of community natural resource use plan

comment.narrative: Baseline to be measured in 1st 3 months of project
Declines by 50 by year 5 compared with baseline levels

1 Due to ongoing awareness and enforcement programmes there has been a further 10 decline thus making it a total of 20 decline in the mangrove felling during the reporting period
2 Fishing ban period of one and half months from 15th April 2014 to 31st May is maintained by the local fishing communities
2 About 150 375 operational mechanized boats are using correct fishing gear till date due to project interventions and
3 MTR suggested removing this indicator as it a long term process and will actually bear effective result only after the project period
Declines by 50 by year 5 compared with baseline levels

Compendium of best practices on mainstreaming biodiversity for key production sector

2 By the end of 2015 when all the sectoral plans are in place their findings will be incorporated into the Compendium of Best Practices

description.narrative: Sectorspecific biodiversitycompatible plans

comment.narrative: Sectoral plans for Fisheries Aquaculture Salt pans Manufacturing units Ports and Shipping Tourism

1 Sector Plans viz Oil Natural Gas Tourism Fisheries and Aquaculture were prepared and key recommendations were discussed among the stakeholders and policy makers through the national level combined consultation workshop conducted on 25th May 2015 2 Key recommendations of the Fisheries and Aquaculture sectors have been incorporated in the AP State Fisheries Action Plan prepared during 2015 and 3 Best practices recommended by the Fisheries Tourism and Aquaculture sectoral plans are under implementation At least 510 good practices for biodiversity conservation are taken up in collaboration with Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation Andhra Pradesh Forest Department Andhra Pradesh Fisheries Department and local stakeholders
Sectoral plans for Fisheries Aquaculture Salt pans Manufacturing units Ports and Shipping Tourism

1 Sector Plans viz Oil Natural Gas Tourism Fisheries and Aquaculture were prepared and key recommendations were discussed among the stakeholders and policy makers through the national level combined consultation workshop conducted on 25th May 2015 2 Key recommendations of the Fisheries and Aquaculture sectors have been incorporated in the AP State Fisheries Action Plan prepared during 2015 and 3 Best practices recommended by the Fisheries Tourism and Aquaculture sectoral plans are under implementation At least 510 good practices for biodiversity conservation are taken up in collaboration with Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation Andhra Pradesh Forest Department Andhra Pradesh Fisheries Department and local stakeholders

description.narrative: Decline in pesticide concentration in the effluents of aqua farms in the target landscape indicator baselines and targets will have to be revisited once the Sector Plans are prepared by midterm

comment.narrative: Baseline concentrations to be measured in 1st 3 months of project
7080 decline over baseline concentrations

The effluents released from the 10 more aquaculture farms were collected and analyzed at reputed lab at Hyderabad As all the 33 samples during 2014 were collected during winter month further to cross check the values 10 more samples were collected and analyzed No drastic seasonal variations were found All these results showed that there is a drastic decline in the pesticide concentrations in aqua farms as the State Government of Andhra Pradesh has introduced a disease resistant exotic species Litopenaeus vannamei Moreover the pesticides like Endosulphan and Nuvan have been banned by the Government from use
7080 decline over baseline concentrations

The effluents released from the 10 more aquaculture farms were collected and analyzed at reputed lab at Hyderabad As all the 33 samples during 2014 were collected during winter month further to cross check the values 10 more samples were collected and analyzed No drastic seasonal variations were found All these results showed that there is a drastic decline in the pesticide concentrations in aqua farms as the State Government of Andhra Pradesh has introduced a disease resistant exotic species Litopenaeus vannamei Moreover the pesticides like Endosulphan and Nuvan have been banned by the Government from use

description.narrative: Effluents from manufacturing units indicator baselines and targets will have to be revisited once the Sector Plans are prepared by midterm

comment.narrative: Baseline to be defined in consultation with the Pollution Control Board at time of approval of Sector Plans
Decline of 7080 over baseline

Negotiated with the Godavari Knowledge Park who are working on the coastal and marine biotechnology Farmer friendly solutions are initiated through improved technology to overcome the above problem Exposure trips for the farmers are being planned to the best practice areas in Gujarat Stakeholders consultation meetings are proposed to discuss a comprehensive study to be undertaken in collaboration with APPCB to understand cumulative impact of pollution load in the natural ecosystem of the EGREE region Further sectoral plans will be approved in the Governing Body meeting
Decline of 7080 over baseline

Negotiated with the Godavari Knowledge Park who are working on the coastal and marine biotechnology Farmer friendly solutions are initiated through improved technology to overcome the above problem Exposure trips for the farmers are being planned to the best practice areas in Gujarat Stakeholders consultation meetings are proposed to discuss a comprehensive study to be undertaken in collaboration with APPCB to understand cumulative impact of pollution load in the natural ecosystem of the EGREE region Further sectoral plans will be approved in the Governing Body meeting

description.narrative: Management Effectiveness Evaluation MEE Scorecard

comment.narrative: Baseline to be measured in 1st 3 months of project
MEE score improves by 20 by year 3 of the project and 30 by year 5

The new Management Plan for the period 20132023 is in place with monitoring protocol An independent MEE team would assess the management effectiveness of Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary and contribute to the MoEFCC monitoring report The MTR gave highly satisfactory rating for this indicator
MEE score improves by 20 by year 3 of the project and 30 by year 5

The new Management Plan for the period 20132023 is in place with monitoring protocol An independent MEE team would assess the management effectiveness of Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary and contribute to the MoEFCC monitoring report The MTR gave highly satisfactory rating for this indicator

description.narrative: Use of correct fishing gear by commercial fishing operations indicator baselines and targets will have to be revisited once the Sector Plans are prepared by midterm

comment.narrative: Limited use baseline to be measured in 1st 3 months of project
By project end at least 7080 of commercial fishing operations are using correct fishing gear

1 About 150 375 operational mechanized boats are using correct fishing gear till date due to project interventions and
2 MTR suggested removing this indicator as it a long term process and will actually bear effective result only after the project period
By project end at least 7080 of commercial fishing operations are using correct fishing gear

1 About 150 375 operational mechanized boats are using correct fishing gear till date due to project interventions and

description.narrative: Sectoral planning in the EGREE mainstreams biodiversity conservation considerations
By project end any new manufacturing units entering the licensing process in the EGREE are subject to the CRZ 2010 Guidelines

comment.narrative: By project end any new manufacturing units entering the licensing process in the EGREE are subject to the new guidelines that also incorporate climate change considerations

Not Applicable Will be rated in Final Evaluation
However the following information is provided as per the discussions held during MTR 1 The Project has initiated coordination with one of the World Bank projects called SICOM mainly for coastal zone management and will initiate integrated coastal zone management plan for EGREE region 2 The climate change studies and Evaluation of Ecosystem Studies are completed and the final report is being finalized for the EGREE region therefore this component can be evaluated during the Final Evaluation 3 The VKPCPIR corridor is under consideration and the process for it is almost finalized The negative impacts of the corridor on the ecology of the area which should be counterbalanced through various environmental mitigation measures have already been discussed in the two public hearings conducted till date In connection with the to be established LNG floating terminal and expansion of Kakinada Sea Port huge dredging activities are being under taken near Hope Island which protects Kakinada City from natural calamities Concerns and modifications required were presented and shared with concerned authorities by the GoIUNDPGEFGoAP Project team and 4 Also the combined 2nd NPSC meeting has agreed to propose the site as a Ramsar Site and the proposal has been moved in this regard
By project end any new manufacturing units entering the licensing process in the EGREE are subject to the new guidelines that also incorporate climate change considerations

Not Applicable Will be rated in Final Evaluation
However the following information is provided as per the discussions held during MTR 1 The Project has initiated coordination with one of the World Bank projects called SICOM mainly for coastal zone management and will initiate integrated coastal zone management plan for EGREE region 2 The climate change studies and Evaluation of Ecosystem Studies are completed and the final report is being finalized for the EGREE region therefore this component can be evaluated during the Final Evaluation 3 The VKPCPIR corridor is under consideration and the process for it is almost finalized The negative impacts of the corridor on the ecology of the area which should be counterbalanced through various environmental mitigation measures have already been discussed in the two public hearings conducted till date In connection with the to be established LNG floating terminal and expansion of Kakinada Sea Port huge dredging activities are being under taken near Hope Island which protects Kakinada City from natural calamities Concerns and modifications required were presented and shared with concerned authorities by the GoIUNDPGEFGoAP Project team and 4 Also the combined 2nd NPSC meeting has agreed to propose the site as a Ramsar Site and the proposal has been moved in this regard

description.narrative: Establishment of crosssectoral institutional mechanism with representation from conservation livelihood and production sectors

comment.narrative: 1 EGREE Foundation a crosssectoral institutional mechanism an initiative of GoIUNDPGEFGoAP Godavari Project has been established under the Andhra Pradesh Societies Registration act 2001 2 The Governing Board of the Foundation was established by the State Government GO MS No 68 dated 14082014 Organized 1st Governing Board Meeting on 30th October 2014 3 The MTR suggested that a District level committee has to be constituted for closer monitoring and can assist the Governing Board effectively MTR also suggested to avoid incorporation of privateindustry members in the EGREE Foundation as it may impact the unbiased functioning and successful implementation of the long term objectives of the project

1 EGREE Foundation a crosssectoral institutional mechanism an initiative of GoIUNDPGEFGoAP Godavari Project has been established under the Andhra Pradesh Societies Registration act 2001 2 The Governing Board of the Foundation was established by the State Government GO MS No 68 dated 14082014 Organized 1st Governing Board Meeting on 30th October 2014 3 The MTR suggested that a District level committee has to be constituted for closer monitoring and can assist the Governing Board effectively MTR also suggested to avoid incorporation of privateindustry members in the EGREE Foundation as it may impact the unbiased functioning and successful implementation of the long term objectives of the project

description.narrative: Incentives for production sector companies to promote biodiversity friendly practices by giving them opportunities for marketing advertising their efforts

comment.narrative: By Year 2 at least 23 companies take up this incentive By year 5 at least 10 companies take up this incentive

The EGREE Foundation has been established during December 2013 and the Governing Board has also been established The protocols and guidelines to achieve the goals of cross sectoral platform mechanism for mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity are yet to be approved by the Governing Board in view of the recent recommendations and course corrections proposed in the MTR The EGREE Foundation is collaborating with Global Reporting Initiative India for training on sustainable reporting and certification of the ecofriendly industries of the region
By Year 2 at least 23 companies take up this incentive By year 5 at least 10 companies take up this incentive

The EGREE Foundation has been established during December 2013 and the Governing Board has also been established The protocols and guidelines to achieve the goals of cross sectoral platform mechanism for mainstreaming coastal and marine biodiversity are yet to be approved by the Governing Board in view of the recent recommendations and course corrections proposed in the MTR The EGREE Foundation is collaborating with Global Reporting Initiative India for training on sustainable reporting and certification of the ecofriendly industries of the region

description.narrative: Landscape level Strategic Plan that provides an enabling policy environment for mainstreaming biodiversity conservation into production sectors

comment.narrative: 1 Strategic Plan

1 The Biodiversity Friendly Strategic Plan BFSP prepared and submitted to MoEFCC and the same has been forwarded to the Government of Andhra Pradesh for implementation 2 As there were several landscape level changes in the project area in the last couple of years the committee suggested revisiting the strategic plan and 3 A consultant was hired for upgrading the Biodiversity Friendly Landscape and Seascape level Plan in view of latest findings and the work has been initiated
1 Strategic Plan

1 The Biodiversity Friendly Strategic Plan BFSP prepared and submitted to MoEFCC and the same has been forwarded to the Government of Andhra Pradesh for implementation 2 As there were several landscape level changes in the project area in the last couple of years the committee suggested revisiting the strategic plan and 3 A consultant was hired for upgrading the Biodiversity Friendly Landscape and Seascape level Plan in view of latest findings and the work has been initiated

description.narrative: Amount of resources available for funding the Foundation and the compliance of approved sectoral plans

comment.narrative: NA

Financial sustainability strategy prepared
Atleast 50 of costs for the foundation covered by regular government and other resources
Atleast 50 of compliance of approved sectoral plans funded

1 MSME Micro Small and Medium EnterprisesDevelopment Institute Visakhapatnam which is implemented under ministry of MSME Government of India has given training to the 35 youth in the EGREE operation area for the livelihood diversification The institute has given assurance for long term collaorations with EGREE Foundation
2 SMART Skills for Manufacturing of Apparel through Research Training which is the supported organization of Ministry of Textiles Government of India has offered Rs 500 Lakhs worth of machineries and services to impart textile training for the local communities in large scale which will further help develop alternate livelihood opportunities in the region Trained members have been linked with DRDA programmes apparel industries Totally 50 members have been trained at 50 institutional fees
3 The project is negotiating to depute one representative from each line departmentsector Panchayat in the District Local Administration to coordinate and communicate with EGREE Foundation in the project area for effective cofunding and implementation of crosssectoral plans prepared by the UNDPGEF Godavari Project
4 The corporate giants like Reliance are willing to tie up with EGREE Foundation to execute livelihood activities through their CSR CER funds Similarly Corporate Environment Responsibility CER allocation from productioncorporate sectors by the end of the project the Foundation itself will be in compliance to continue the programme through EGREE Foundation Advocacy programmes conducted till date with all the corporates in the EGREE Region are showing a very positive response and the corporates are showing interest in the objectives of the project
5 Due to awareness and advocacy programmes conducted till date almost all the line departments Enforcement Institutions Community institutions in the EGREE Region are showing very positive response and participating and adopting the recommendations suggestions provided and are conducting the awarenesscommunity strengtheningenforcement programmes in the objective of the project which is a good sign for future programmes as the plan is for EGREE Foundation to become a resource centre for the region
6 A decision has been taken in the NPSC meeting for designating the EGREE Foundation as ENVIS Centre httpenvisnicinabouthtml wherein the Government of India will support for issuing newsletters

Atleast 50 of costs for the foundation covered by regular government and other resources
Atleast 50 of compliance of approved sectoral plans funded

1 MSME Micro Small and Medium EnterprisesDevelopment Institute Visakhapatnam which is implemented under ministry of MSME Government of India has given training to the 35 youth in the EGREE operation area for the livelihood diversification The institute has given assurance for long term collaorations with EGREE Foundation
2 SMART Skills for Manufacturing of Apparel through Research Training which is the supported organization of Ministry of Textiles Government of India has offered Rs 500 Lakhs worth of machineries and services to impart textile training for the local communities in large scale which will further help develop alternate livelihood opportunities in the region Trained members have been linked with DRDA programmes apparel industries Totally 50 members have been trained at 50 institutional fees
3 The project is negotiating to depute one representative from each line departmentsector Panchayat in the District Local Administration to coordinate and communicate with EGREE Foundation in the project area for effective cofunding and implementation of crosssectoral plans prepared by the UNDPGEF Godavari Project
4 The corporate giants like Reliance are willing to tie up with EGREE Foundation to execute livelihood activities through their CSR CER funds Similarly Corporate Environment Responsibility CER allocation from productioncorporate sectors by the end of the project the Foundation itself will be in compliance to continue the programme through EGREE Foundation Advocacy programmes conducted till date with all the corporates in the EGREE Region are showing a very positive response and the corporates are showing interest in the objectives of the project
5 Due to awareness and advocacy programmes conducted till date almost all the line departments Enforcement Institutions Community institutions in the EGREE Region are showing very positive response and participating and adopting the recommendations suggestions provided and are conducting the awarenesscommunity strengtheningenforcement programmes in the objective of the project which is a good sign for future programmes as the plan is for EGREE Foundation to become a resource centre for the region
6 A decision has been taken in the NPSC meeting for designating the EGREE Foundation as ENVIS Centre httpenvisnicinabouthtml wherein the Government of India will support for issuing newsletters

description.narrative: Strategies developed for ensuring that existing sector policies mainstream biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: Policies requiring amendments identified in Year 1
Strategies developed for 100 of identified policies

1 Main policies that require harmonization have been identified The Project is keenly examining amending the Wildlife Protection Act 1972 for inclusion of coastal and marine biodiversity conservation which have already been adopted in advanced countries having the similar wildlife laws 2 For the 1st time in India with the intervention of UNDPGEF Godavari Project a separate chapter on Marine Conservation has been included in the proposed Wild Life Action Plan of India from 2017 to 2031 15 years 3 Amending Andhra Pradesh Marine Fisheries Act to be in line with the aquaculture sector expansion mesh size regulations etc as recommended by the Aquaculture and Fisheries sectoral plans of GoIUNDPGEFGoAP project These were discussed with all stakeholders during the National level Consultation Workshop organized during 25th May 2015 Inputs were given on the draft Fisheries Action Plan of AP State Government and 4 Coromandel Fertilizers Kakinada operating in the EGREE Region is one of the foremost industries to incorporate the biodiversity friendly practices into their operations with the support of EGREE Foundation Coromandel Fertilizers as part of their compliance has to allot 50 of its land for plantations However the site selected for the plantation was a wetland which is a good habitat for waterbirds especially Darters In fact this habitat is recorded as home to the 2nd largest Darter population in India after Gujarat When Coromandel Fertilizers was about to start conversion of the wetland into plantation EGREE Foundation intervened and liaised with the State Pollution Control Board and assisted in obtaining permission for protecting the wetlands by requesting the local Forest Officials to provide wetland plant species which could be shown as plantations for fulfilment of forest environmental compliance With this initiative the EGREE Foundation could mainstream biodiversity conservation into production sector in around 30 acres Further EGREE Foundation was able to conserve the second largest habitat of Darters in India
Strategies developed for 100 of identified policies

1 Main policies that require harmonization have been identified The Project is keenly examining amending the Wildlife Protection Act 1972 for inclusion of coastal and marine biodiversity conservation which have already been adopted in advanced countries having the similar wildlife laws 2 For the 1st time in India with the intervention of UNDPGEF Godavari Project a separate chapter on Marine Conservation has been included in the proposed Wild Life Action Plan of India from 2017 to 2031 15 years 3 Amending Andhra Pradesh Marine Fisheries Act to be in line with the aquaculture sector expansion mesh size regulations etc as recommended by the Aquaculture and Fisheries sectoral plans of GoIUNDPGEFGoAP project These were discussed with all stakeholders during the National level Consultation Workshop organized during 25th May 2015 Inputs were given on the draft Fisheries Action Plan of AP State Government and 4 Coromandel Fertilizers Kakinada operating in the EGREE Region is one of the foremost industries to incorporate the biodiversity friendly practices into their operations with the support of EGREE Foundation Coromandel Fertilizers as part of their compliance has to allot 50 of its land for plantations However the site selected for the plantation was a wetland which is a good habitat for waterbirds especially Darters In fact this habitat is recorded as home to the 2nd largest Darter population in India after Gujarat When Coromandel Fertilizers was about to start conversion of the wetland into plantation EGREE Foundation intervened and liaised with the State Pollution Control Board and assisted in obtaining permission for protecting the wetlands by requesting the local Forest Officials to provide wetland plant species which could be shown as plantations for fulfilment of forest environmental compliance With this initiative the EGREE Foundation could mainstream biodiversity conservation into production sector in around 30 acres Further EGREE Foundation was able to conserve the second largest habitat of Darters in India

description.narrative: Improvement in Systemic Level Indicators of Capacity Development Scorecard

comment.narrative:
SYSTEMIC LEVEL
1 Capacity to conceptualize and formulate policies legislations strategies programme 67
2 Capacity to implement policies legislation strategies and programmes 33
3 Capacity to engage and build consensus among all stakeholders 17
4 Capacity to mobilize information and knowledge 33
5 Capacity to monitor evaluate and report and learn at the sector and project levels 33

description.narrative: To mainstream coastal and marine biodiversity conservation into production sectors in the East Godavari River Estuarine Ecosystem EGREE
Landscapeseascape area in the EGREE where production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: 0 ha
About 80000 ha 46450 ha as area of direct influence and 33550 ha as area of indirect influence

Within the reporting period the project activities have directly influenced about 45000 ha The detailed activities are elaborated below
A Increased level of protection of Mangroves and other habitats and enforcement in association with Coast Guard Navy and Fisheries Department B Improvement of the existing mangrove habitat by mangrove plantations of 60 acres during the reporting period C Marine Turtle National Workshop was organized for reviving turtle conservation networks in the eastern coastal states of India Training on turtle stranding for preventing turtle deaths was carried out and an Action Plan for the East Coast States of India was also discussed The outcomes of all the recommendations was compiled into a Vizag Declaration for conservation of Marine Turtles in India Preliminary proceedings cum action plan was done and detailed proceedings under preparation D Promoting Community Based EcoTourism in and around Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary and adjoining Reserve Forest areas E Coastal beach cleanup programmemes involving Coast Guard Marine Police youth local schools colleges and industries F Strengthening of enforcement departments Coast Guard Marine Police Fisheries Forest Departments etc for conserving the biodiversity of EGREE region through joint monitoring programme G Involving Corporate Sectors in Coastal and Marine Biodiversity Conservation
H Biodiversity conservation programmes were conducted for 75 Nature clubs in local schools and colleges to increase the awareness levels among the students through Wildlife Week Celebrations International Coastal Cleanup Day and Exhibitions Workshops Biodiversity Day celebrations etc I CBOs EDCs VSS SHGs further strengthened for mangrove protection and conservation and J Promotion of alternative livelihoods for reducing dependency on forests through training to youth groups on EcoTourism based NatureGuide Hospitality management and Cookery SMART programme for village girls and women on apparel training and designing center in collaboration with ATDC Hyderabad
2 Approximately 28000 ha area was indirectly influenced during the reporting period through the following
A Awareness programmes B Setting up of awareness hoardings 30 all around the EGREE Region C Increased Knowledge levels of stakeholders through publications viz booklets 1 book 1 brochures 7 posters 7 handouts 2 standees 20 D Increased awareness through Kalajatha Programmes 60 similar to street play and E 1st time in India presented the urgent need to mitigate human wildlife conflict between fishing cat and fisherman and also between otters and fishermanaquaculture farmers with appropriate statistics at National government level
About 80000 ha 46450 ha as area of direct influence and 33550 ha as area of indirect influence

Within the reporting period the project activities have directly influenced about 45000 ha The detailed activities are elaborated below
A Increased level of protection of Mangroves and other habitats and enforcement in association with Coast Guard Navy and Fisheries Department B Improvement of the existing mangrove habitat by mangrove plantations of 60 acres during the reporting period C Marine Turtle National Workshop was organized for reviving turtle conservation networks in the eastern coastal states of India Training on turtle stranding for preventing turtle deaths was carried out and an Action Plan for the East Coast States of India was also discussed The outcomes of all the recommendations was compiled into a Vizag Declaration for conservation of Marine Turtles in India Preliminary proceedings cum action plan was done and detailed proceedings under preparation D Promoting Community Based EcoTourism in and around Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary and adjoining Reserve Forest areas E Coastal beach cleanup programmemes involving Coast Guard Marine Police youth local schools colleges and industries F Strengthening of enforcement departments Coast Guard Marine Police Fisheries Forest Departments etc for conserving the biodiversity of EGREE region through joint monitoring programme G Involving Corporate Sectors in Coastal and Marine Biodiversity Conservation
H Biodiversity conservation programmes were conducted for 75 Nature clubs in local schools and colleges to increase the awareness levels among the students through Wildlife Week Celebrations International Coastal Cleanup Day and Exhibitions Workshops Biodiversity Day celebrations etc I CBOs EDCs VSS SHGs further strengthened for mangrove protection and conservation and J Promotion of alternative livelihoods for reducing dependency on forests through training to youth groups on EcoTourism based NatureGuide Hospitality management and Cookery SMART programme for village girls and women on apparel training and designing center in collaboration with ATDC Hyderabad
2 Approximately 28000 ha area was indirectly influenced during the reporting period through the following
A Awareness programmes B Setting up of awareness hoardings 30 all around the EGREE Region C Increased Knowledge levels of stakeholders through publications viz booklets 1 book 1 brochures 7 posters 7 handouts 2 standees 20 D Increased awareness through Kalajatha Programmes 60 similar to street play and E 1st time in India presented the urgent need to mitigate human wildlife conflict between fishing cat and fisherman and also between otters and fishermanaquaculture farmers with appropriate statistics at National government level

description.narrative: Improvement in Total Capacity Development Scorecard

comment.narrative: Will be evaluated in the Terminal Evaluation
Will be evaluated in the Terminal Evaluation

description.narrative: of open degraded mangrove areas in the project area reduced to the minimum
Population size of birds including migratory remains stable or increases

comment.narrative: Baseline to be collected in Year 1
Population size remains at least stable or increases

1 The waterbird population in the EGREE region has been estimated in the entire landscapeseascapecoastline with the support of this project and the population is found to be 36786 birds comprising of 266 species This is an approximately 2 increase from that of previous years population AND 2 The GODAVARI Project initiative helped in recording 16 new bird species between January 2012 and June 2015 from the EGREE region The publication Waterbirds of EGREE book was published by the project team which includes the current status of 131 waterbird species recorded in EGREE Region
Population size remains at least stable or increases

1 The waterbird population in the EGREE region has been estimated in the entire landscapeseascapecoastline with the support of this project and the population is found to be 36786 birds comprising of 266 species This is an approximately 2 increase from that of previous years population AND 2 The GODAVARI Project initiative helped in recording 16 new bird species between January 2012 and June 2015 from the EGREE region The publication Waterbirds of EGREE book was published by the project team which includes the current status of 131 waterbird species recorded in EGREE Region

description.narrative: Percentage of allocation of CSR expenditures of production sectors aligned with landscapelevel Strategic Plan for the EGREE

comment.narrative: Limited link with biodiversity conservation objectives
At least 50 of the CSR budget of production sectors aligned with biodiversity conservation and sustainable livelihoods objectives at the landscape level

1 Due to the UNDPGEF Godavari Projects initiatives in the EGREE Region for the past three years around 31 of the CSR budget of production sectors is now aligned for biodiversity conservation and enhancing sustainable livelihood programmes to communities 2 Corporates like Coromandel International Ltd Reliance Foundation GMR Foundation Cairn Energy ONGC GSPC etc have approached the GODAVARI Project team for seeking appropriate programmes like livelihood enhancement village development mangrove restoration massive awareness programmes etc towards which they can allocate their CSR funds 3 The Corporte sectors supported for the following awareness programmes campaigns like World Biodiversity day Wildlife Week Celebrations BioAndhra Beach Festival 2015 Exhibitions Workshops which are the initiatives of GoIUNDPGEFGoAP GODAVARI Project in collaboration with APFD Godavari Knowledge Park Jana Vignana Vedika PR Govt College APTDC during this reporting period 4 Coromandel International Ltd has approached EGREE Foundation for providing support to establish about 80 acres of plantation With their support over 700 birds were rescued during HudHud cyclone and provided medical care and support till they were able to fly The APPCB also directed Coromandel International Ltd to consult EGREE Foundation regarding plantation related issues Action plans were accordingly designed and executed in the field 5 Reliance Foundation has assured support for livelihood development programmes initiated by GoIUNDPGEFGoAP GODAVARI Project in the following villages viz Gadimoga Chinnavalasala Peddavalasala and Lakshmipathi Puram 6 Confederation of Indian Industries CII Hyderabad has promised to deploy a person to support further mainstreaming of coastal and marine biodiversity conservation initiatives proposed in the sectoral plan into production sectors
At least 50 of the CSR budget of production sectors aligned with biodiversity conservation and sustainable livelihoods objectives at the landscape level

1 Due to the UNDPGEF Godavari Projects initiatives in the EGREE Region for the past three years around 31 of the CSR budget of production sectors is now aligned for biodiversity conservation and enhancing sustainable livelihood programmes to communities 2 Corporates like Coromandel International Ltd Reliance Foundation GMR Foundation Cairn Energy ONGC GSPC etc have approached the GODAVARI Project team for seeking appropriate programmes like livelihood enhancement village development mangrove restoration massive awareness programmes etc towards which they can allocate their CSR funds 3 The Corporte sectors supported for the following awareness programmes campaigns like World Biodiversity day Wildlife Week Celebrations BioAndhra Beach Festival 2015 Exhibitions Workshops which are the initiatives of GoIUNDPGEFGoAP GODAVARI Project in collaboration with APFD Godavari Knowledge Park Jana Vignana Vedika PR Govt College APTDC during this reporting period 4 Coromandel International Ltd has approached EGREE Foundation for providing support to establish about 80 acres of plantation With their support over 700 birds were rescued during HudHud cyclone and provided medical care and support till they were able to fly The APPCB also directed Coromandel International Ltd to consult EGREE Foundation regarding plantation related issues Action plans were accordingly designed and executed in the field 5 Reliance Foundation has assured support for livelihood development programmes initiated by GoIUNDPGEFGoAP GODAVARI Project in the following villages viz Gadimoga Chinnavalasala Peddavalasala and Lakshmipathi Puram 6 Confederation of Indian Industries CII Hyderabad has promised to deploy a person to support further mainstreaming of coastal and marine biodiversity conservation initiatives proposed in the sectoral plan into production sectors

description.narrative:
Population size of following critical species remains stable or increases
Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea IUCN threatened
Olive Ridley turtle IUCN vulnerable status
Fishing cat IUCN status is endangered

comment.narrative:
Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea 70 numbers
Olive Ridley Turtle 300 annually
Fishing cat 112 as per 2001 census

Population size stable increasing as follows
Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea increase
Olive Ridley turtle stability
Fishing cat at least stable or increase

1 Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea is Stable 2 Nesting habitats of the Olive Ridley Turtle both at Sacramento and Hope Island were protected between January and May The four year hatching success rate shows more or less a stabilized nestings But nesting vs hatching ratio has increased from 9141 in 2013 to 93 in 2014 and 2015 No of Nesting females have also increased from 439 in 2014 to 571 in 2015 3 Population of Fishing Cat and Indian Smooth Coated Otter are monitored through direct sighting camera traps and indirect sign surveys which indicated that the numbers is stable Intensive Grid Level Surveys are being carried out to understand behavior pattern of these animals Village level surveys being carried out to address the conservation issues and sensitize villages towards conservation of these animals and 4 The MTR suggested renaming this indicator as Red Data Index instead of species specific indicators

Population size stable increasing as follows
Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea increase
Olive Ridley turtle stability
Fishing cat at least stable or increase

1 Scyphiphora hydrophyllacea is Stable 2 Nesting habitats of the Olive Ridley Turtle both at Sacramento and Hope Island were protected between January and May The four year hatching success rate shows more or less a stabilized nestings But nesting vs hatching ratio has increased from 9141 in 2013 to 93 in 2014 and 2015 No of Nesting females have also increased from 439 in 2014 to 571 in 2015 3 Population of Fishing Cat and Indian Smooth Coated Otter are monitored through direct sighting camera traps and indirect sign surveys which indicated that the numbers is stable Intensive Grid Level Surveys are being carried out to understand behavior pattern of these animals Village level surveys being carried out to address the conservation issues and sensitize villages towards conservation of these animals and 4 The MTR suggested renaming this indicator as Red Data Index instead of species specific indicators

description.narrative: 1. Establish a of cross-sectoral institutional mechanism in EGREE with representation from conservation, livelihood and production sectors. 2. Preparation of one Landscape Level Strategic Plan (SP) that provides enabling policy environment for mainstreaming biodiversity conservation into production sectors. 3. Undertake 2 Research studies on East Godavari River Estuarine Ecosystem (EGREE) 4. Number of community conservation knowledge center complex centers established 5. Number of workshops organized on landscape conservation and marine diversity 6. Number of exposure visits organised 7. Number of Knowledge products developed 8. One Management Plan revised

comment.narrative: 1. 0 2. 0 3. Limited number of research studies on EGREE available 4.0 5.0 6.0 7.0 8.0

1. Prepare Whale Shark Conservation Action Plan 2. Organize national level closure workshop 3. Establish a Community Knowledge Centre for initiating inter-departmental jointly owned micro projects in collaboration with the government and private sector institutes.

1. Dissemination of information on protection of whale shark has been launched across fishing habitations for protection of the whale shark. 2. The closure workshop has been planned for January, 2020. 3. The Community Knowledge Centre has been established to initiate micro-projects to benefit the communities across coastal villages.

1. Revising the bylaws of EGREE Foundation to cover the Andhra Pradesh coast as opposed to the project site of East Godavari district alone. 2. Conducting a nation wide dialogue on economic evaluation of ecosystem services of Marine Protected Areas in India 3. Conduct a national corporate summit with a focus on mainstreaming biodiversity into production centers 4. Establishing a Knowledge Management Centre 5. Plan an exit strategy

1. The bylaws have been revised in conformity with the approved role of EGREE Foundation beyond the project period as per decisions taken in the Government Body meeting of EGREE Foundation 2. The Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change has conducted a national consultation in July, 2018 on the economic evaluation of ecosystem services to share the learnings of the study "Economic Valuation of Ecosystem Services" conducted by Wildlife Institute of India under the project. 4. The contract for establishing the Knowledge Management Centre has been awarded. The work is under progress and will be finalised next year 5. Exit strategy being developed
The project is operationally closed.
The project is operationally closed.
